title: Custom class and {dplyr} compatibility
text: R commonly used language data science statistical computing. Foundational data structures allow manipulation data minimal effort cognitive load. One commonly required data structures tabular data. can represented R ways, example matrix data frame. data frame (class data.frame) flexible tabular data structure, can hold different data types (e.g. numbers, character strings, etc.) across different columns. contrast matrices – arrays dimensions – thus can hold single data type. Data frames can even nested, cells can data frames lists. therefore clear data frames prevalent. However, without limitations. relatively basic printing method can fload R console number columns rows large. useful methods (e.g., summary() str()), might appropriate certain types tabular data. cases useful utilise R’s inheritance mechanisms (specifically S3 inheritance) write extensions R’s data.frame class. case data frame superclass new subclass extends inherits methods (see Adv R1 details S3 inheritance). One common extension data frame tibble {tibble} R package. Outlined {tibble}‘s ’Tibbles’ vignette2, tibbles offer improvements printing, subsetting recycling rules. Another commonly used data frame extension data.table class {data.table} R package 3. class primarily designed improve performance (.e. speed efficiency operations storage) working tabular data R. process developing R software (likely R package), new tabular data class builds atop data frames can become beneficial. blog post two main sections: brief overview steps required setup class extends data frames guide technical aspects class invariants design implementation decisions, tidyverse compatibility
code: # data frame can hold heterogeneous data types across different columns data.frame(a = c(1, 2, 3), b = c(4, 5, 6), c = c("a", "b", "c")) #>   a b c #> 1 1 4 a #> 2 2 5 b #> 3 3 6 c  # each column must be of the same type df <- data.frame(a = c(1, 2, 3), b = c("4", 5, 6)) # be careful of the silent type conversion df$a #> [1] 1 2 3 df$b #> [1] "4" "5" "6"  mat <- matrix(1:9, nrow = 3, ncol = 3) mat #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    1    4    7 #> [2,]    2    5    8 #> [3,]    3    6    9 mat[1, 1] <- "1" # be careful of the silent type conversion mat #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,] "1"  "4"  "7"  #> [2,] "2"  "5"  "8"  #> [3,] "3"  "6"  "9" df <- data.frame(a = "w", b = "x") df[1, 1][[1]] <- list(c = c("y", "z")) df #>      a b #> 1 y, z x  df <- data.frame(a = "w", b = "x") df[1, 1][[1]] <- list(data.frame(c = "y", d = "z")) df #>      a b #> 1 y, z x

title: Custom class and {dplyr} compatibility
text: useful write class constructor function can called create object new class. functions define redacted version (readability) functions defined package. ’s ’s needed create subclass data frame. However, although ’ve created class haven’t given functionality thus identical data frame due inheritance. can now write many methods want. show two methods, one require writing generic second . See Adv R4 Epiverse blog post5 find S3 generics. Useful resources “Writing custom data class” section: extending tibbles functionality
code: birthdays <- function(x) {     # the vector of classes is required for it to inherit from `data.frame`   structure(x, class = c("birthdays", "data.frame")) } print.birthdays <- function(x, ...) {   cat(     sprintf(       "A `birthdays` object with %s rows and %s cols",       dim(x)[1], dim(x)[2]     )   )   invisible(x) }  birthdays_per_month <- function(x, ...) {   UseMethod("birthdays_per_month") }  birthdays_per_month.birthdays <- function(x, ...) {   out <- table(lubridate::month(x$birthday))   months <- c(     "Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun",     "Jul", "Aug", "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec"   )   names(out) <- months[as.numeric(names(out))]   return(out) }

title: Custom class and {dplyr} compatibility
text: Moving onto second section post, discuss design choices creating using S3 classes R. Class invariants members class define . words, without elements class fulfil basic definition. therefore sensible make sure class contains elements times (least operations applied class). cases class object contains invariants normal service can continued. However, case invariant missing modified non-conformist type (e.g. date converted numer) decision made. Either code can error, hopefully giving user informative message modification broke object; alternatively, subclass can revoked superclass can returned. almost cases superclass (.e. base class inherited ) general won’t class invariant restrictions. example class, <birthdays>, invariants column called name must contain characters, column called birthday must contain dates. order rows columns considered invariant property, extra columns names data types also allowed. number rows also invariant can many birthdays like data object. present cases well considerations technical details options. ’ll demonstrate cases subset function R (subsetting uses single square bracket tabular data, [). First fail--subsetting. write subsetting function useful function checks object class valid, -called validator function. return error class valid (defined terms class’ invariants). Now can show error one invariants removed subsetting. second design option reconstruct--subsetting. checks whether class valid, downgrade class superclass, case data frame. done validating object subsetting check whether valid class object, either ensuring attributes subclass – case <birthdays> – maintained, attributes stripped attributes base superclass – case data.frame – kept. Important note: section post relies heavily https://github.com/DavisVaughan/2020-06-01_dplyr-vctrs-compat. four functions required added ensure class correctly handled invaliding : birthdays_reconstruct() birthdays_can_reconstruct() df_reconstruct() dplyr_reconstruct.birthdays() ’ll tackle first three first, move onto last one requires extra steps. birthdays_reconstruct() function contains -else statement determine whether returned object <birthdays> data.frame object. -else evaluation controlled birthdays_can_reconstruct(). function determines whether subsetting object valid <birthdays> class. check whetther validator fails, case returns FALSE, otherwise function return TRUE. next function required df_reconstruct(). called object judged valid <birthdays> object simply copies attributes <birthdays> class object subset. three functions defined reconstruction can added package subsetting function order subset <birthdays> objects returning either <birthdays> objects still valid, data frames invalidated. design benefit conducting data exploration user faced error, can continue data frame, informed message printed console birthdays_reconstruct().
code: validate_birthdays <- function(x) {   stopifnot(     "input must contain 'name' and 'birthday' columns" =       all(c("name", "birthday") %in% colnames(x)),     "names must be a character" =       is.character(x$name),     "birthday must be a date" =       lubridate::is.Date(x$birthday)   )   invisible(x) } `[.birthdays` <- function(x) {   validate_birthdays(NextMethod()) }  birthdays[, -1] #  Error in validate_birthdays(NextMethod()) : #  input must contain 'name' and 'birthday' columns birthdays_reconstruct <- function(x, to) {   if (birthdays_can_reconstruct(x)) {     df_reconstruct(x, to)   } else {      x <- as.data.frame(x)     message("Removing crucial column in `<birthdays>` returning `<data.frame>`")     x   } } birthdays_can_reconstruct <- function(x) {   # check whether input is valid   valid <- tryCatch(     { validate_birthdays(x) },     error = function(cnd) FALSE   )    # return boolean   !isFALSE(valid) } df_reconstruct <- function(x, to) {   attrs <- attributes(to)   attrs$names <- names(x)   attrs$row.names <- .row_names_info(x, type = 0L)   attributes(x) <- attrs   x } `[.birthdays` <- function(x, ...) {   out <- NextMethod()   birthdays_reconstruct(out, x) }

title: Custom class and {dplyr} compatibility
text: order able operate <birthdays> class using functions package {dplyr}, common data frames, need make function compatible. function dplyr_reconstruct.birthdays() comes . dplyr_reconstruct() generic function exported {dplyr}. called {dplyr} verbs make sure objects restored input class invalidated. Information generic can found {dplyr} help documentation. explained help documentation, {dplyr} also uses two base R functions perform data manipulation. names<- (.e names setter function) [ one-dimensional subsetting function. therefore define methods custom class order dplyr_reconstruct() work intended. wraps need adding function perform data manipulation using reconstruction design outlined . However, final housekeeping . cases {dplyr} package dependency (either imported suggested), S3 generic dplyr_reconstruct() required loaded. R versions 3.6.0 – also works R versions later 3.6.0 – generic function needs registered. done writing .onLoad() function, typically file called zzz.R. included package illustrative purpose. s3_register() function used .onLoad() also needed added package function kindly supplied {vctrs} {rlang} unlicensed thus can copied another package. See R packages6 information .onLoad() attaching loading general. Since R version 3.6.0 S3 generic registration happens automatically S3Method() package namespace7 using {roxygen2} documentation #' @exportS3Method dplyr::dplyr_reconstruct. package depend R >= 3.6.0 thus can use mechanism automatically register {dplyr} generic. one last option prevents hard dependency relatively recent R version. Since {roxygen2} version 6.1.0, @rawNamespace tag allows insertion text NAMESPACE file. Using tag following code check local R version register S3 method equal 3.6.0. three options registering S3 methods different benefits downsides, choice depends specific use-case. time may best use --date methods packages maintain last handful R releases8. Compatibility {vctrs} also possible using mechanism (functions) described post, interested see https://github.com/DavisVaughan/2020-06-01_dplyr-vctrs-compat details. blog post compendium information sources linked cited throughout. Please refer sites information primary source citation work.
code: dplyr_reconstruct.birthdays <- function(data, template) { # nolint   birthdays_reconstruct(data, template) } ?dplyr_extending ?dplyr::dplyr_reconstruct `[.birthdays` <- function(x, ...) {   out <- NextMethod()   birthdays_reconstruct(out, x) }  `names<-.birthdays` <- function(x, value) {   out <- NextMethod()   birthdays_reconstruct(out, x) } .onLoad <- function(libname, pkgname) {   s3_register("dplyr::dplyr_reconstruct", "birthdays")   invisible() } #' @rawNamespace if (getRversion() >= "3.6.0") { #'   S3method(pkg::fun, class) #' }
